NIZATIDINE

H2-RECEPTOR ANTAGONISTS

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Exceptions to legal category
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Benign gastric, duodenal or NSAID-associated ulceration,

By mouth

  • For adults
    300 mg once daily for 4–8 weeks, dose to be taken in the evening, alternatively 150 mg twice daily for 4–8 weeks; maintenance 150 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.

Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150–300 mg twice daily for up to 12 weeks.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid unless essential.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Manufacturer advises caution.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use half normal dose if eGFR 20–50 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Use one-quarter normal dose if eGFR less than 20 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Sweating,

rare: Fever, hyperuricaemia, nausea, vasculitis,

Directions for administration

Avoid rapid intravenous injection (risk of arrhythmias and postural hypotension).

For intravenous infusion, give continuously or intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%. For continuous infusion, dilute 300 mg in 150 mL and give at a rate of 10 mg/hour; for intermittent infusion, dilute 100 mg in 50 L and give over 15 minutes.

Exceptions to legal category

Nizatidine can be sold to the public for the prevention and treatment of symptoms of food-related heartburn and meal-induced indigestion in adults and children over 16 years; max. single dose 75 mg, max. daily dose 150 mg for max. 14 days.

Prepared medicinal forms of NIZATIDINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, oral suspension,
Capsule
